content.body: We don‚Äôt seem to have any where a definition of what _‚Äútransient activation‚Äù_ or _‚Äútransient user activation‚Äù_ is.
content.formatted_body: We don‚Äôt seem to have any where a definition of what ‚Äútransient activation‚Äù or ‚Äútransient user activation‚Äù is.

content.body: I mean, I developer-friendly definition (vs something for implementors that‚Äôs just implied through what‚Äôs affected by the relevant spec requirements).
Is it possible to state in one or two sentences what _‚Äútransient activation‚Äù_ actually means?
content.formatted_body: Is it possible to state in one or two sentences what ‚Äútransient activation‚Äù actually means?

content.body: Does it mean ‚Äúrequires a user gesture‚Äù? Or does it mean more than that?
* We don‚Äôt seem to have anywhere a definition of what _‚Äútransient activation‚Äù_ or _‚Äútransient user activation‚Äù_ is.

content.body: I take it that maybe it means, the entire browsing context is one that‚Äôs somehow known to have been triggered by a user gesture, and therefore for all features within that browsing context that would normally be considered to require a separate user gesture, the user gesture is considered to have already happened?
Does ‚Äútransition activation‚Äù mean the same thing as saying the user gesture has been _‚Äúpropagated‚Äù_? Or are those two things not synonymous (but instead there‚Äôs some more complex relation)?
content.formatted_body: Does ‚Äútransition activation‚Äù mean the same thing as saying the user gesture has been ‚Äúpropagated‚Äù? Or are those two things not synonymous (but instead there‚Äôs some more complex relation)?

content.body: Draft definition: https://pr7962.content.dev.mdn.mozit.cloud/en-US/docs/Glossary/Transient_activation

> **Transient activation** (or "transient user activation") is a window state that indicates a user has recently pressed a button, moved a mouse, used a menu, or performed some other user interaction.
content.formatted_body: Transient activation (or "transient user activation") is a window state that indicates a user has recently pressed a button, moved a mouse, used a menu, or performed some other user interaction.

content.body: PR at https://github.com/mdn/content/pull/7962

Domenic: no I missed that. My concern was more that a caller might want something like str.substring(0,10), but is okay with getting back shorter strings and doesn't want to truncate the length argument based on the input
content.formatted_body: Domenic: no I missed that. My concern was more that a caller might want something like str.substring(0,10), but is okay with getting back shorter strings and doesn't want to truncate the length argument based on the input

content.body: Domenic: and similarly you might want to do str.substring(5,1), but be okay with getting back the empty string for strings that are not at least 6 long
content.formatted_body: Domenic: and similarly you might want to do str.substring(5,1), but be okay with getting back the empty string for strings that are not at least 6 long

content.body: https://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-webappsec/2021Aug/0009.html reading Martin Thompson say that he finds some part of a spec ‚Äúmind-numbingly arcane‚Äù, I no longer feel so bad for similar mind-numbness I feel when reading some specs. Kind of feel like I‚Äôm in pretty good company now‚Ä¶

this makes me think the entire *navigate* algorithm should ideally have normative domintro box saying something meaningful for normal readers about what the algorithm does and what some key points/effects are
content.formatted_body: this makes me think the entire navigate algorithm should ideally have normative domintro box saying something meaningful for normal readers about what the algorithm does and what some key points/effects are

content.body: and in general, for other algorithms, across our core specs
‚Ä¶because people do read actually those algorithms and try to exfiltrate some understanding from them

content.body: I feel like only people who actually have a clear understanding of the **navigate** algorithm are the editors who wrote it and the *maybe* implementors who implemented it ‚Äî but I suspect even the implementors, to (re)understand it, would end up needing to go back and look at the code they wrote, rather than the prose of the spec

content.body: And to be clear, I‚Äôm not complaining about the quality of spec prose ‚Äî¬†just saying it‚Äôs kind of inherently going to be arcane to pretty much anybody. And so supplementing it with some kind of non-normative domintro intro or outro could help a bit for orienting readers.

content.body: looks

I'm a bit skeptical if https://github.com/html5lib/html5lib-tests/blob/master/tokenizer/domjs.test#L197 is worth enough having that it makes sense to expose more API surface in a parser implementation in order to pass it.
What's the challenge there? Needing to know whether the source string came from endianness-unknown UTF-8/16 etc.?

> <@gsnedders:mozilla.org> What's the challenge there? Needing to know whether the source string came from endianness-unknown UTF-8/16 etc.?

Being able to turn off BOM removal.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @gsnedders:mozilla.org
What's the challenge there? Needing to know whether the source string came from endianness-unknown UTF-8/16 etc.?
Being able to turn off BOM removal.

content.body: per spec, BOM removal is part of the decode step in Encoding, right?

> <@gsnedders:mozilla.org> per spec, BOM removal is part of the decode step in Encoding, right?

Yes, but it's a bit fictitious for formats that support internal encoding declarations and, therefore, have format-internal logic.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @gsnedders:mozilla.org
per spec, BOM removal is part of the decode step in Encoding, right?
Yes, but it's a bit fictitious for formats that support internal encoding declarations and, therefore, have format-internal logic.

content.body: I'm less happy about exposing the sniffing limit esp if https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/6962 happens, but no exposing that one seems to block a whole lot of other patches. And that also seems to be in a low-level building block anyway.
`master` is now missing only 5 changesets from `validator-nu` and 2 of those are in-flight for m-c, so I'll probably merge them tomorrow.
content.formatted_body: master is now missing only 5 changesets from validator-nu and 2 of those are in-flight for m-c, so I'll probably merge them tomorrow.

content.body: The three patches that will be left are the hardest one (ambiguous ampersand) and the null doctype thing, which I'm inclined to say is a spec bug.
Null doctype name, that is.

Another possibility is merging the null doctype patches after ensuring the change isn't Web-visible, but it seems silly to have this kind of tokenizer-level difference from what's exposed via the DOM.
Yeah the ambiguous-ampersand one is a beast. But if I recall correctly I at least did finally manage to get that one passing all html5lib tests. So at least it is spec-conforming.

content.body: At this point, I can‚Äôt even remember the context for that one‚Ä¶

It was the addition I made the last time round I tried to merge a patch affecting EOF-in-template error reporting, but I solved it in a different way that's forward-compatible with Firefox perhaps becoming able to visualize EOF-triggered errors.
aha, yeah, recalling that template stuff
anyway the main end goal I had with all the open PRs/patches I wrote was that we could set up CI to run the html5lib test suite so that we could catch any regressions

being certain that we separately confirm we are conforming to the spec was a secondary concern for me :) because I work on faith that the html5lib tests are written to conform to the actual spec requirements

Perhaps it's the least churn for everyone if I just merge the doctype stuff and ensure that it's not Web-visible. But it would be sad if we now have so many project depending on the test suite that it's no longer worthwhile to change the spec or suite.
also I think for the HTML checker behavior, most (or maybe none) of these changes actually make no difference ‚Äî¬†so it‚Äôs been hard for me to feel much direct pain about any issues with them
The ones that affect Firefox View Source definitely affect the checker, too.

> <@hsivonen:mozilla.org> Perhaps it's the least churn for everyone if I just merge the doctype stuff and ensure that it's not Web-visible. But it would be sad if we now have so many project depending on the test suite that it's no longer worthwhile to change the spec or suite.

yeah I agree not being able to bring the test suite into conformance with the spec is not good
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @hsivonen:mozilla.org
Perhaps it's the least churn for everyone if I just merge the doctype stuff and ensure that it's not Web-visible. But it would be sad if we now have so many project depending on the test suite that it's no longer worthwhile to change the spec or suite.
yeah I agree not being able to bring the test suite into conformance with the spec is not good

content.body: but it seems to me like there are not that many projects that are using the test suite and would definitely break / need to change their implementations
I mean, it seems like it‚Äôs on the order of just 6 or 7?
Not sure how many there are.

My primary concern is that leaving this oddity in could make non-browser-DOM APIs diverge from browsers in what they expose. However, probably no one care about what the non-browser API expose for doctype.
I think most of the non-browser implementations would not be resistant to changing their code. But it‚Äôs the browser projects that would.
Does any browser project even run the tokenizer tests?

> However, probably no one care about what the non-browser API expose for doctype.
Bingo. I would think so too.
content.formatted_body:
However, probably no one care about what the non-browser API expose for doctype.

content.body: Firefox runs them only on the Java level.
